Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of PS-3 Automated Peptide Synthesizer to Enhance Research and Training at Texas A&M International University

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1335988
Gupta

This MRI project proposal requests funds for an automated PS3 peptide synthesizer system to
facilitate the expansion of a peptide chemistry laboratory at Texas A&M International University
(TAMIU), a Hispanic serving institution in South Texas. To foster the continued expansion
of research at TAMIU and to better provide educational/research opportunities for their students,
this proposal requests funding for equipment that will: 1) contribute to the limited understanding
of the mechanism by which cell penetrating peptides (CPPs) translocate cell membranes; 2)
increase knowledge of which key spider silk peptides are associated with specific mechanical
properties; 3) elucidate the mechanisms of carbohydrates receptors responsible for malignant
behavior of cancerous cells 4) provide training and access a research methodology to a large
number of predominantly Hispanic students, who are historically underrepresented in math and
science professions; 5) augment the education experience of several existing biology courses
and enable the creation of an additional elective chemistry course on polymers; 6) foster
intramural and extramural collaborations, and 7) increase TAMIU?s competitiveness for extramural
research funding and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Peptide Synthesizer acquired under this project has been instrumental in the execution of many projects which includes developing new areas of research, development of new synthetic pathways to help synthesize new analogs, developing faculty competence in combinatorial synthesis, preparing both undergraduate and graduate students to explore new areas of research and incorporating research in teaching chemistry thereby developing enduring learning experiences.

Capability to synthesize organo-peptide molecules in a multi-step synthesis: One of the aims of the project was to synthesize carbohydrate receptors (lectin mimics) and test binding activity with monosaccharides using spectroscopy. The overaching goal was to develop a synthetic route that can be used to synthesize analogs that will help understand lectin-carbohydrate recognition process. This multi-step synthesis has been successful. Preliminary results have been presented in conferences and a graduate thesis will be presented to the graduate school of Texas A&M International in December 2016 by a graduating student. The importance of multiple hydrogen bonding in carbohydrate recognition have been discovered in the preliminary data and will serve as hypothesis for developing further receptors towards achieving stronger binding of lectin mimics in aqueous media. The synthetic pathway created allows researchers to design analogs for structure activity relationship studies with the aim to better understand lectin-carbohydrate interactions. The ease of automation has reduced the time that it took for us to synthesize complex analogs. There should be enough data to publish several papers based on the study of the compounds synthesized.  All of these projects (current and future) require the versatility of the synthesizer.

Enhancement of Teaching and Undergraduate Research: In active learning laboratory experiments the acquisition of the synthesizer has allowed us to design experiments that produce enduring learning. Students are being supplied with amino acids and allowed to set their programs to synthesize oligopeptides and then characterized via MALDI (this was done via remote access with UTSA).  The exercise is both frustrating and rewarding for them but that is the reality of science. The practice of designing and executing experiments also helps prepares students for life in graduate school or in an industrial research and development setting. Two student undergraduate posters will be submitted for presentation at the American Chemical Society meeting in the Spring of 2017. This instrument coupled with others has helped provide quality holistic chemistry education for minority students. This will help bridge the gap of minorities in science.

Human resource development: Graduate and undergraduate students employed as interns, research assistants and managers have been trained with vital skills that will help them succeed in the scientific workforce. Some have actually been encouraged to pursue graduate programs in organic chemistry and analytical chemistry. A pipeline for training/developing the next generation minority scientist has been created. The generation of preliminary data which has been presented at conferences has boosted the interests of students to pursue further education.
